Chapter 3 Literature review In this chapter, I review some literature relating to the core problem that I am concerned with in this thesis. I begin by discussing the general problem of inferring absence of a cryptic, incipient pest species population. In particular, I emphasise that the problem requires the marriage of separate mathematical modelling cultures; (a) mathematical/ecological modelling, and (b) statistical inference. 3.1 Inferring absence of cryptic pests The primary problem this work is concerned with is to infer the absence of a cryptic pest species. A cryptic species is any species which is hard to detect. One example is snakes, which are small, immobile, camouflaged, and located in inaccessible habitats (Inferring the Absence of a Species: A Case Study of Snakes, Kery 2002). 3.2 The standard approach to inferring absence of a cryptic species The standard approach to this problem is given by McArdle (1990). In this section, I outline the standard existing approach to inferring pest absence. Let \(N \in \mathbb N\) be the size of the population. Let \(p \in [0, 1]\) be the probability that a species is detected in any given sampling unit. Then, the probability of detecting the species is \[ \alpha = \Pr(X = 0) = 1 - (1 - p)^T. \] McArdle suggests 3 types of question that could be answered with such a model. 1. 3.3 Probability models 3.4 Barnes et al. 3.5 Intro to Medfly In this section, I motivate further study by introducing the example of the Mediterranean fruit fly (Ceratitis capitata). 3.5.1 Economic importance of the fruit fly 3.5.2 Medfly detection problems Medfly have low dispersal. Chapter 4 A generalised model of pest species detection 4.1 Introduction In the previous chapter, I reviewed recent work by Barnes et al. on inferring absence of a cryptic pest species. I concluded the chapter by discussing some of the models restricting assumptions, and how they affect the realism of the model. In this chapter I propose to develop a general model that relaxes the restrictive assumptions. In particular, I give a general description of the model, followed by some concrete proposals for model specification (e.g. prior distributions). Because this model is analytically intractable, Monte Carlo sampling is proposed. In particular, I discuss the virtues and vices of applying Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) sampling for this problem. 4.2 Model specification The basic model is composed of (a) a growth model and (b) a detection model. 4.3 Sampling
